Government effort to regulate religious freedom has negatively impacted minority religions and the courts have failed to protect their rights according to recent findings by a Penn State researcher PERIOD

 said Roger Finke professor of sociology PERIOD

Finke is the coauthor of a study that analyzed more than  cases dealing with religion that came before the courts from  and  PERIOD His study particularly focused on analyzing  cases involving the First Amendment and free exercise of religious freedom PERIOD

The study shed new light on the Employment Division Department of Human Resources of Oregon vs PERIOD Smith decision of  the first case to document the court decision and its adverse effect on minority religions PERIOD

In the case two men Alfred Smith and Galen Black were fired from their jobs at a private drug rehabilitation organization because they ingested peyote for sacramental purposes during a Native American Church ceremony PERIOD Both were members of the church PERIOD After the two men were dismissed from their positions they filed for unemployment but were determined ineligible by their former employer who said the two men were discharged for  misconduct according to the FindLaw Web site www.findlaw.com PERIOD

The Oregon Court of Appeals reversed the determination and said  according to the Web site PERIOD

The case deals with  Finke said PERIOD

The analysis by Finke and coauthor John Wybraniec a former doctoral student in sociology at Purdue University found minority religions are far less likely to be handed a favorable ruling in court PERIOD

The study also shows Christian and nonChristian minority religions are more likely to be involved in court cases than mainstream denominations and churches PERIOD

 Finke added PERIOD

Finke includes a variety of religions in his study from a wide range of religious faiths PERIOD Some of these denominations include Mormons Jehovahs Witnesses American Indian religions Muslims and Protestant sects such as the Assemblies of God PERIOD

Nondenominational or independent Christian churches Jews and Roman Catholics also have a poorer chance of being handed a favorable ruling said Finke when compared to more established Protestant churches PERIOD

Established faiths such as the Methodist Presbyterian and Episcopalian are more likely to have ruling come in their favor because they are more closely identified with those of the majority mainstream American society Finke added PERIOD

But Finke also noted new religions are becoming more prevalent within society PERIOD
